Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploiting synthetic GPCRs and mating factors as extracellular sensors for substrate-dependent assembly of complex cellulosomes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1263719/1263768/1263799
Chen/Robinson/Da Silva

The primary obstacle impeding the more widespread use of biomass for energy and chemical production is the absence of a low-cost technology for overcoming the recalcitrance of these materials. Cellulosomes are self-assembled multi-enzyme complexes found in many anaerobic microorganisms that are highly efficient for biomass depolymerization. The group of investigators have successfully developed a synthetic yeast consortium displaying a functional cellulosome for biofuel production. However, given the complexity of the different members involved in the consortium, engineering cell to cell coordination is the key in maintaining the required overall functionality. Their goal in this project is to design synthetic extracellular sensors that can be used to regulate the secretion of enzymes and adaptor scaffoldins involved in the assembly of the appropriate complex cellulosome structure in a substrate-dependent manner. The proposed research is scientifically significant because it will provide a general framework for the design of extracellular sensors that are important for other bioprocessing or biomedical applications. Moreover, graduate students participating in this research will gain an integrated perspective of the important interfaces and synergies connecting biochemistry, modern genetics, and process engineering to solve an important problem of our society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering microbes to utilize lignocellulose contributes to the efficient, economical, and environmentally friendly conversion of biomass. The controlled display of the appropriate enzymes on the cell surface requires the ability to sense the cellulose or hemicellulose present. The key concept of this collaborative project was the design of extracellular sensors that can detect the external biomass composition and coordinate the expression and secretion of the required enzymes and adaptors in yeast. The research at UCI focused on the development of an extracellular glucose sensor for the regulated secretion of cellulases. Using this sensor, we evaluated the expression and secretion of three different cellulase enzymes as a function of glucose concentration, and demonstrated that the system responds to the extracellular glucose level. We also demonstrated the specificity of the sensor to glucose, and that no inhibition by xylose occurs (important for a mixture of cellulose and hemicellulose). Using a switch from galactose to glucose, the kinetics of transcription activation was evaluated. Rapid activation was observed with an effective response time of less than 30 minutes. Finally, we enhanced the secretion of the cellulases to improve sensitivity. We evaluated multiple interventions in the yeast secretory pathway, and demonstrated substantial increases (2-4-fold) in extracellular cellulase level.

In addition to the contributions toward the microbial utilization of biomass, the approach for the sensing circuit can be adapted for the detection of other extracellular metabolites. Similarly, the various interventions for improving protein secretion are broadly applicable for other proteins and for membrane transporter processing. This research contributed to the training of undergraduate and graduate students, including from underrepresented groups.
